title: Larry Fink's Latest Sermon
summary: The BlackRock CEO auditions to be the next Treasury Secretary.. BlackRock CEO Larry Fink is among the world's most powerful investment managers, but it seems he longs for more influence. To wit, he has assumed a role as self-styled conscience of the business world in telling CEOs how to run their companies.

title: Courting More Clarity
summary: The Supreme Court takes up religious liberty and the Electoral College.. The Supreme Court agreed Friday to hear two big cases crying out for legal clarity. The first is whether the government can force nuns to provide contraception for their employees against their religious beliefs. The second is whether states can penalize so-called faithless electors in the Electoral College.

title: Inslee's Climate of Illegality
summary: A court says Washington's Governor can't impose cap and trade by fiat.. Good news: The political panic over climate change doesn't justify one-man rule. That's the message the Washington Supreme Court delivered this week to Governor Jay Inslee, who tried to impose his command-and-control agenda by fiat.

title: Trump, Obama and the Spending Power
summary: The White House didn't commit a crime in delaying aid to Ukraine.. Does anyone remember Democrats or Republicans calling for President Obama's impeachment after a federal court reproached his Administration for lawlessly spending money? We didn't think so, but now Democrats are flogging a new report by the Government Accountability Office claiming that President Trump broke the law by briefly delaying military aid to Ukraine last summer. The agency's legal conclusion is wrong, but the double standard is worse.

title: Best Buy Opens Probe Into CEO's Personal Conduct
summary: Anonymous letter alleges Corie Barry had romantic relationship with fellow senior executive; CEO cooperating with probe. The board of Best Buy Co. is investigating allegations that Chief Executive Corie Barry had an inappropriate romantic relationship with a fellow executive, who has since left the electronics retailer.

title: Boeing Encounters New MAX Woes
summary: Plane maker is working to correct glitch affecting flight-control computers. Boeing Co. is grappling with still another software problem that has cropped up in its effort to fix its 737 MAX aircraft, adding to technical issues that have complicated and delayed the grounded fleet's return to service over many months.

title: Boomer Socialism Led to Bernie Sanders
summary: Government policies limit millennials' prosperity, Harvard economist Edward Glaeser argues. Will they realize more of the same isn't the answer?. Cambridge, Mass.

title: The Comey Coverup Unravels
summary: The FBI, the CIA and the press all have much to be embarrassed about.. In a curious report on Thursday evening, the New York Times carefully averts its eyes from everything that's interesting. Even Adam Schiff has acknowledged that James Comey's actions in 2016 may represent the most important and significant Russian influence on the election. (Hoist your shot glass. This will be the umpteenth time I've quoted Mr. Schiff on this matter in this column.)

title: The Left Forgets What Martin Luther King Stood For
summary: He didn't think oppression was what defined the struggle for civil rights.. As the nation celebrates the birth of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the progressive left will again seize the moment to twist the story of black Americans' struggle, to the detriment of those who suffered most in that struggle. They'll put all the attention on the oppressive conditions faced by black freedom fighters-what white racists did to them-rather than on their own spirit in fighting to gain equal rights under the law. Instead of celebrating blacks' achievements and the progress made toward delivering on America's promissory note, the left will transport yesterday's real injustices into today's false social-justice narrative, ignoring the principles that were so crucial to Dr. King.

title: New York Tries Again to Muzzle Pro-Life Groups
summary: The state's new 'boss bill' defies the spirit of a 2018 Supreme Court ruling in favor of a pregnancy center.. The National Institute of Family and Life Advocates can't catch a break. Not two years after battling a California law all the way to the Supreme Court in Nifla v. Becerra-and winning-the Virginia-based pro-life organization is now suing New York state officials over legislation that undermines the ability of its Empire State member centers to hire workers who support their mission. The law "violates our very reason for being," says Anne O'Connor, Nifla's vice president of legal affairs.

title: Advice for NASA's Star Intern
summary: New planets don't turn up every day so keep your feet on the ground.. Seventeen-year-old Wolf Cukier discovered a new planet. The high-school senior from Scarsdale, N.Y., accomplished this last summer on his third day as an intern at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: The Lawyers Who Will Lead Trump's Impeachment Defense
summary: Trump's legal team has longtime allies and frequent cable-news guests.

title: Supreme Court to Look at Electoral College Rules
summary: High court to consider whether presidential electors can vote for candidate not chosen in state popular vote. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to take a rare look at rules for electing U.S. presidents, saying it will decide whether a state's appointed presidential electors can vote in the Electoral College for a candidate who didn't win the state's popular vote.

title: Spotify in Talks to Buy the Ringer
summary: The Ringer, founded in 2016 by former ESPN commentator Bill Simmons, has over 30 podcasts. Spotify Technology SA is in talks to buy sports and pop-culture outlet the Ringer, according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would let the audiostreaming giant break into broader digital media and bring a network of more than 30 podcasts under its roof.

title: ICE Director Says New York's Sanctuary Policy Led to Killing of Queens Woman
summary: Mayor's spokeswoman disagrees and says, 'Fear, hate and attempts to divide are signatures of the Trump administration'. Acting Immigration and Customs Enforcement Director Matthew Albence on Friday blamed the murder of a 92-year-old woman in Queens earlier this month on New York City's sanctuary policy, which he said protects illegal immigrants with criminal convictions.

title: China's Slowing Growth Underlines Stress Facing Its Economy in 2020
summary: With trade, investment, consumer spending and business confidence all in retreat, some economists warn economy could slip further. SHENZHEN, China-A newly sealed trade truce with the U.S. reduced a key source of anxiety for Chinese policy makers but leaves them with another challenge: a need to boost consumer and business confidence as the country faces more downward pressure on its massive economy.

title: USDA Proposes Easing School Lunch Healthy Eating Rules
summary: Opponents say changes would make it easier to choose pizza and burgers over balanced meals. Federal regulators proposed giving schools more flexibility for student meal programs, a move that opponents said could encourage less-healthy eating.

title: Countertop Maker Clio Files for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy
summary: Private-equity backed countertop maker formed from roll up of other manufacturers has been hurt by tariffs on imported Chinese quartz. Countertop maker Clio Holdings LLC, created from the roll up of a number of smaller players, is closing its doors after failing to integrate its businesses and suffering from both the Trump administration's tariffs imposed during the U.S.-China trade war and by separate, more recent duties on imported Chinese quartz.

title: Former Barbadian Official Found Guilty of Laundering Bribes
summary: Donville Inniss was accused of taking bribes from an insurance company while minister of industry. A former minister of industry for the island nation of Barbados was convicted Thursday of laundering bribes he allegedly received from an insurance company that was seeking to renew a public contract.

title: Morgan Stanley Cuts CEO James Gorman's Bonus
summary: Wall Street firm hits its financial targets and sets new ones, but a sluggish stock price takes its toll. Morgan Stanley paid its chief executive, James Gorman, $27 million for his work in 2019, a pay cut for a year when the bank's revenue hit a record but its shares lagged behind those of rivals.

title: U.S. Stocks End Week at Record Levels
summary: The rally coincides with the signing of a trade deal between the U.S. and China. U.S. stocks set repeated highs this week, pulled higher by shares of big technology companies.

title: Judge Slashes Damages in J&J Risperdal Case to $6.8 Million From $8 Billion
summary: J&J had been ordered to pay in suit involving its antipsychotic drug Risperdal. A Philadelphia judge has reduced the amount of punitive damages Johnson & Johnson must pay in a lawsuit over its antipsychotic Risperdal to $6.8 million from the $8 billion awarded by a jury in October.

title: ThoughtSpot Names CFO As it Eyes Public Offering
summary: Mohit Daswani joins the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based analytics company after senior roles at Square and PayPal. ThoughtSpot Inc. hired its first finance chief as the analytics company looks to grow its business and prepare for a potential initial public offering.

title: What Did GAO Staff Know and When Did They Know It?
summary: Judging the organization by its own standards.. Yesterday this column asked why Americans should take the opinion of the Government Accountability Office seriously when it claims a Trump violation of law. Reviewing the same set of facts, House Democrats allege no such violation in their impeachment articles. The details of the GAO's argument raise more questions-including whether the GAO itself has faithfully followed the law.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Decline After Treasury Announces New Bond Sales
summary: Department plans to begin sales of 20-year bonds later this year. Yields on longer-term U.S. government debt climbed Friday after the Treasury Department said it would begin selling 20-year government bonds later this year.

title: High Court to Review Exemptions to Birth Control Mandate
summary: Justices will hear Trump administration's appeal of rulings that blocked rules nationwide. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed to consider the legality of Trump administration rules that broadened moral and religious exemptions to an Affordable Care Act provision requiring employer-provided health-insurance plans to cover birth control with no out-of-pocket costs.

title: Djibouti Rejects Court Ruling to Hand Back Container Terminal
summary: The East African country took over the Doraleh box terminal and gave control to China. Djibouti has rejected a U.K. court ruling to hand back control of a container terminal to global port operator DP World, after taking it over two years ago and allowing a Chinese state entity to build a separate terminal for the growing African market.

title: Wells Fargo Shareholders Have Been Left Behind in Stock-Market Rally
summary: Shares of the bank are back where they started before its sales-practices scandal erupted in 2016. Shares of Wells Fargo & Co. are back where they started before the bank's sales-practices scandal erupted in 2016, despite the stock's bumpy ride.

title: Canada to Make Payments to Families Affected by Downing of Airliner
summary: Trudeau says he also expects Iran to compensate the families. OTTAWA-Canada intends to offer immediate financial help to families of Canadian citizens and residents who were killed when Iran last week downed a Ukrainian commercial jetliner, adding it expects full compensation from Tehran.

title: To Understand America, Look to Its College Sports
summary: Nowhere else on Earth is so much money spent in pursuit of the amateur ideal. As we approach Super Bowl weekend, the closest thing America has to a national cultural festival, I'm struck that one of the great pleasures and puzzles of life for an immigrant here is the nature of sports and their primacy in the national consciousness.

title: 'The Age of Entitlement' Review: The Dividing Line
summary: The political tribalism of today has its roots in the debates and reforms of the 1960s.. For the poet Philip Larkin, "life was never better" than in the spring of 1963. So too it seems for Christopher Caldwell and America. For what happened afterward "came with costs that proved staggeringly high-in money, freedom, rights, and social stability." Too high, in fact. Mr. Caldwell's argument and analysis in "The Age of Entitlement: America Since the Sixties" bring to mind another of Larkin's most famous lines-the one about your Mum and Dad and what they did to your life. Mr. Caldwell thinks that, as things turned out, it wasn't just you they messed up. It was the whole country.

title: The U.S. Hasn't Planted This Little Wheat in More Than a Century
summary: Chicago wheat prices are up 25% from September, lifted by fewer plantings, quality issues and Australia's lower production. The last time that U.S. farmers planted so few acres with winter wheat, William Howard Taft was president and the opening salvos of World War I were still five years away.

title: 8 Predictions for the Future of Fashion
summary: Expect sci-fi diamonds, AI-enhanced skin care, bridesmaids in suits and more advancements beyond the Jetsons' wildest dreams. "I think we should roar more," proclaimed Paris-based creative director and stylist Catherine Baba. Given that we're in the '20s once again, and judging by the countless 1920s-themed New Year's Eve parties documented on Instagram earlier this month, she might get her wish. "The [1920s] was a shaking-up decade...[it] was so diverse and liberating," Ms. Baba said, drawing parallels between the transitional creative climates then and now. She describes the prototypical flapper look as "so rich" but guesses that the 1920s' freewheeling spirit will influence designers more conceptually than literally. Fashion historian Laura McLaws Helms, however, doesn't rule out the possibility of specific nods to flapper style on the runways of the near future. "It will be a response to people hoping [the 2020s] are going to be like what they imagined the 1920s were-which isn't necessarily what they really were," she said. So, more Gatsbian party frocks, fewer references to social division and Prohibition.

title: Luminus Offers $14.5 Million for Bankrupt Celadon's Taylor Express
summary: The deal for the trucking company is subject to higher bids. New York investment firm Luminus Management LLC has offered $14.5 million to acquire the Taylor Express Inc. business of bankrupt truckload carrier Celadon Group Inc., subject to higher bids at a possible auction.

title: In South China Sea Confrontation, Indonesia Resists China-Cautiously
summary: Southeast Asian nations try to counter Beijing's moves without provoking a painful backlash. JAKARTA, Indonesia-In late December, several Chinese coast guard ships escorted more than three dozen Chinese fishing boats into the waters off Indonesia's Natuna Islands.

title: A Mystery Meets the Mystical
summary: Presenting a web of secular and religious images, the Wilton Diptych's meanings are still disputed.. It is small, roughly 15 by 21 inches; tempera on oak. It is the oldest Northern European painting in London's National Gallery, housed in an intimate, darkened anteroom. It is a portable altarpiece for private devotion, with secular and spiritual significance. It is gorgeous, its tiniest details exquisitely handled, in a style called International Gothic. And we know very little for certain about it-not its exact date, nor its maker, nor its precise purpose. It is the Wilton Diptych, named for its long residence at Wilton House near Salisbury in Wiltshire, England, before it reached its current home in 1929.

title: Tech Upstarts Say Tech Giants Abuse Market Power to Stifle Competition
summary: Midsize firms tell lawmakers about difficulties of competing with Google, Amazon and Apple. WASHINGTON-Four midsize technology companies told Congress that industry giants use their market power to beat back their businesses, an unusual public airing of criticism that suggests antitrust probes of the companies are gaining steam.

title: Supreme Leader Rallies Iranians, Praises Attacks on U.S. Bases
summary: Iran's highest religious and political authority led Friday prayers in Tehran for the first time in eight years amid growing domestic unrest and foreign pressure. TEHRAN-Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called the country's attacks on U.S. positions in Iraq a blow to Washington's honor, as he attempted to rally popular support amid pressure over the accidental downing of a Ukrainian passenger jet last week.

title: CDC to Screen Travelers From Central China for New Virus
summary: Move comes as mystery viral pneumonia is spotted in Japan, Thailand after infecting 45 people in central China. People traveling to the U.S. from Wuhan, China, will be screened for fevers, coughs or difficulty breathing, after a new pneumonia-like virus sickened dozens in Asia, U.S. health officials said.

title: Brazil Minister Ousted Over Remarks Echoing Nazi Propaganda
summary: President Jair Bolsonaro fired the culture secretary over a speech he gave that contained phrases from Hitler's propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels.. BRASÍLIA-Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro fired a top cabinet member over a speech he gave that contained phrases from Adolf Hitler's propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels.

title: J.B. Hunt Misses on Fourth-Quarter Earnings
summary: Slipping freight pricing, demand signal weakness in U.S. shipping markets. Transportation bellwether J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. delivered lower-than-expected profits in the fourth quarter, raising concerns for other freight operators.

title: Do Political Campaigns Change Voters' Minds?
summary: Evidence shows that ads almost never affect us the way a personal conversation can. In 2020, at least $6 billion will be spent on political campaigns in the U.S.-over $2 billion on the presidential election alone. These astronomical numbers fuel fears that public opinion will be manipulated, either through traditional techniques like TV ads, cold calling and mailings, or with more sophisticated technology that uses big data for targeted advertising.

title: Court Tosses Youngsters' Climate-Change Suit
summary: Judges don't have power to require the government to phase out fossil-fuel emissions, court says. A U.S. federal appeals court threw out a novel lawsuit alleging the federal government was violating young people's constitutional rights by not doing more to address the harms of climate change.

title: Tesla Unintended-Acceleration Claims to be Reviewed by U.S. Regulators
summary: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it is evaluating 127 complaints against electric-car maker. Federal regulators are looking into whether consumer complaints of unintended acceleration in Tesla Inc . models warrant a formal defect investigation into about 500,000 vehicles sold by the electric-car maker.

title: Lawmakers Call for Investigation of Fintech Firm Yodlee's Data Selling
summary: Members of Congress question whether the Envestnet unit is getting proper consent before selling data; company says it follows applicable laws. WASHINGTON-Financial-data firm Yodlee might be selling consumers' personal financial data without proper consent, three lawmakers said in a Friday letter calling on the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the matter.

title: Imagine Questioning the Managerial Elite
summary: It is pretty easy to understand the outrage of a struggling blue-collar worker when the CEO of Boeing Co. is fired for incompetence but nevertheless receives millions of dollars in an exit bonus.. Michael Lind's essay is spot on in many respects, but the general theme seems to focus on the idea that the lower middle class has turned to populism due to an envy of wealth and influence. I think it also includes a resentment of injustice ("Saving Democracy From the Managerial Elite," Review, Jan. 11). It is pretty easy to understand the outrage of a struggling blue-collar worker when the CEO of Boeing Co. is fired for incompetence but nevertheless receives millions of dollars in an exit bonus. Nor can the average taxpayer justify why elite Ivy League universities may accumulate billions tax-free while their donors write donations off as deductions. And the kicker is when they use all this wealth and power to promote secular and socialist ideology repugnant to the beliefs of those they view as "deplorables."

title: The Philadelphians Voted For Social Justice
summary: Larry Krasner won his race with 75% of the vote. He was clear about his social-justice priorities and voters are getting exactly what was promised.. Jennifer Stefano characterizes Philadelphia's soft-on-crime District Attorney Larry Krasner as one of a new crop of progressive prosecutors in liberal cities ("Philadelphia's Top Prosecutor Pursues 'Social,' Not Actual Justice," Cross Country, Jan. 11). Mr. Krasner campaigned for district attorney on a claim that policing and prosecution are systemically racist.

title: Physics Favors the Wearing Of Bow Ties, Natty or Not
summary: Kindly add venerable pediatricians to your list of gentlemen who favor bow ties for professional wear.. Kindly add venerable pediatricians to your list of gentlemen who favor bow ties for professional wear ("On Trend: Are Bow Ties Better Left to Children and Puppies?," Off Duty, Jan. 11). We have learned by sad experience that long ties dragged through open diapers are not a good look.

title: Roots of U.S.-Iran Hostility Extend to U.S. Coup of 1953
summary: The 1979 revolution was in large part a reaction to the earlier coup and intervening years.. Regarding Eric S. Edelman and Franklin C. Miller's "Hostilities With Iran Began in '79" (op-ed, Jan. 9): To be fair, hostilities with Iran can be traced pretty clearly to the U.S.-U.K. orchestrated coup against democratically elected President Mohammad Mosaddegh in favor of Shah Reza Pahlavi in 1953. The 1979 revolution was in large part a reaction to the earlier coup and intervening years, where the shah crushed internal dissent via the much feared secret police, the Savak, which was established with the help of, among others, the CIA. The Savak tortured and killed thousands of Iranians.

title: Ukraine's Leader Rejects Premier's Resignation Over Leaked Audio
summary: President Zelensky gives the prime minister another chance after he appeared to disparage the Mr. Zelensky's understanding of economics. MOSCOW-Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky rejected the resignation of the country's prime minister following the release of an audio recording in which he appeared to make disparaging comments about Mr. Zelensky's understanding of economics.

title: Employers Pull Back on Posting New Jobs
summary: Other data show unseasonably warm weather affected December home building, utilities output. WASHINGTON-Job openings declined sharply in November, a sign of weakening employer demand that could restrain job growth in 2020.

title: Carlos Ghosn: Just the Latest Strange Object Ferried in a Music Equipment Box
summary: Resume Subscription. Carlos Ghosn's escape from Japan wasn't the first time a celebrity traveled incognito in a large black case designed to transport concert gear.

title: Tasting Bourbon for a Living Is No Party
summary: It's Jackie Zykan's job to make sure Brown-Forman's Old Forester bourbon has a spirited taste; 'you're the only person in the room that's not allowed to be drunk because you're working.'. Jackie Zykan has a whiskey-lover's dream job: tasting bourbon for a living.

title: Thousands of Chinese Students' Data Exposed on Internet
summary: Information leak from facial-recognition database raises questions about school surveillance and cybersecurity in China. A Chinese facial-recognition database with information on thousands of children was stored without protection on the internet, a researcher discovered, raising questions about school surveillance and cybersecurity in China.

title: Trust Banks Have a Need for Spend
summary: Investors seem to want trust banks to further tighten their belts, but that might be shortsighted. When it comes to trust banks' results, it is the expense line that seems to matter right now.

title: 'Elderhood' Review: The Way We Age Now
summary: In 1900, the average life expectancy for an American was 46 years; these days it is 79. But what will those later years be like, and how should we make the most of them?. If books, like movies, were given ratings, Louise Aronson's "Elderhood" ought to be rated PG-80. Not all that many people 80 or older are likely to have living parents, true, but some warning is nevertheless necessary if you have attained to that august (november? december?) age and plan to read her book. Here are just a few gloomy facts that Dr. Aronson, a geriatrician, bestows upon her readers: 5.3 million Americans had one form or another of dementia in 2015, and more than 80% of these were older than 75; 13 million Americans are incontinent (if the phrase "adult diapers" doesn't shiver your timbers, nothing will). Half of all adult Americans over 65 will have some form of arthritis. Immunity from infection and disease lessens with advancing age. Loss of acuity in hearing begins in one's 50s and diminishes further with advancing age. Of sexual activity, about which Dr. Aronson graciously does not provide any dismaying details, let us, too, not speak.

title: 'Lord of All the Dead' Review: The Weight of the Past
summary: The Spanish novelist Javier Cercas wrestles with the legacy of his beloved great-uncle, who met a supposedly glorious end ﬁghting for Franco.. All war stories are derivative of one of two texts: the "Iliad" or the "Odyssey"-that is, the going to or the coming home from war. Put another way, every war story is about either the dead or the survivors. Javier Cercas's "Lord of All the Dead: A Nonfiction Novel" manages to contain both subjects in a single narrative, one that grapples with his family's involvement in the Spanish Civil War. As the title suggests, Mr. Cercas tells a story that is both fiction and nonfiction. The result is a book of reportage through which the dead walk with all the vibrancy of the living.

title: Trinidad: A Caribbean Vacation With an Indian Flavor
summary: The influence of India permeates the island of Trinidad-in the food, music and seaside temples. No wonder Carnival here is such a blast. IF TRINIDAD and Tobago immediately conjure up Calypso, sandy beaches and flip-flops, you're only thinking of the Tobago part. Tourist-focused and largely Afro-Caribbean, Tobago is physically and culturally distinct from the other part of the dual-island republic. Some 95% of the country's population live southwest on Trinidad, an energy-rich, highly energetic island that's geographically closer to Venezuela and spiritually nearer to India.

title: Elated Shareholders Fall Into The Gap
summary: Gap shares surged when they planned to split and jumped again when they canceled those plans, but the period in between was a doozy. Savvy shoppers will pounce on flash sales at stores like Gap. The clothing retailer's investors got a similar opportunity, but their timing had to be nearly perfect.

title: Goodbye, Back Pain? This Office Chair Was Designed by a Trauma Surgeon
summary: For decades, American workers have tried trendy office chairs hoping to alleviate the agony of sitting. Is the new 'Active Stool' the one?. CHANCES ARE you're aware of the need to sit up and sit less at work. But it's often easier to just stay put, roll your shoulders forward and hunch your back, a shape that resembles sketches of those stooping early humans from which we evolved.

title: Airbnb to Tie Employee Bonuses to Guest Safety
summary: Ahead of plans to go public, home-sharing platform emphasizes serving 'stakeholders' that include hosts, guests, investors, employees. Airbnb Inc. said it will factor in metrics including guest safety when awarding employee bonuses, as the company grapples with how best to address crime and other problems at rentals listed on its platform.

title: 'A Time to Build' Review: When All of Politics Is a Stage
summary: Our institutions are weakened when people stop taking them seriously and start treating them instead as platforms for personal performance.. Almost four years ago in his book "The Fractured Republic," Yuval Levin analyzed what he called, in a brilliant phrase, America's "politics of competing nostalgias." Conservatives, he contended, long for a return to the cultural consolidation of the 1950s, when Americans participated in more or less the same customs and drew on the same values; liberals, meanwhile, seek to remake the economic consolidation of the '50s, when tax rates, wages and job security all soared, however briefly. Neither of these historically abnormal states of affairs can be re-created, Mr. Levin insisted. Americans should instead find ways to foster both cultural integrity and economic stability nearer their homes-in their states and cities and local communities-which in turn means suppressing the tendency to nationalize every political question and cultural controversy.

title: 'Imperfect Union' Review: Mr. & Mrs. Pathfinder
summary: In 1856, John Frémont became the ﬁrst Republican candidate for president. His slogan: 'Free Soil, Free Labor, Free Speech, Free Men, Frémont!'. Beginning in the 1840s, John C. Frémont became perhaps the most famous man in America. One mid-19th-century magazine went so far as to identify him-along with Christopher Columbus and George Washington-as one of three pivotal figures in world history since Jesus Christ.

title: Children's Books: Gentle Lessons About Dignity and Difference
summary: A wise, humane book from NPR's Scott Simon tells a mystery from the point of view of a 19-year-old resident of a group home for people with intellectual disabilities.. As there are stars in the sky and grains of sand on the beach, so without number are the children's books devoted to the idea that being "different" is good. Those who depart from the norm not only have value, the argument goes, but probably also possess finer qualities than those who run with the herd. For any young person who has ever felt misjudged or ill at ease-which is everyone, given what it is to grow up-the idea has a satisfying judicial ring to it. Others may deprecate you now, but someday you'll show them.

title: 'Dangerous Melodies' Review: Music in the American Century
summary: An encyclopedic study of the uses and abuses of classical music in the United States from World War I through the Cold War.. Upon its debut in 1991, John Adams's opera "The Death of Klinghoffer," occasioned by the Palestine Liberation Front's 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro, was charged with being anti-Semitic and pro-terrorist. In November 2001, the Boston Symphony Orchestra was pressured to cancel its scheduled performances of three of the haunting "Klinghoffer" choruses, which include a "Chorus of Exiled Palestinians" and a "Chorus of Exiled Jews." The reason offered was that it was too soon after 9/11, especially since the husband of a chorus member had been a passenger on one of the hijacked airplanes. But as recently as 2014, when the Metropolitan Opera at last staged the opera, general manager Peter Gelb succumbed to alleged concerns about public safety and canceled the Met's live cinema simulcasts, though live performances at Lincoln Center were allowed to continue.

title: Fiction: Through the Spyglass of Anthropology
summary: Brassy, big-as-life short stories by the author of 'Their Eyes Were Watching God.'. In the 1920s, Zora Neale Hurston studied at Barnard College under the trailblazing cultural anthropologist Franz Boas, who encouraged her to research the African-American folklore of central Florida, where she had grown up. The project suited her perfectly. As shown in a new collection of her stories, "Hitting a Straight Lick With a Crooked Stick" (Amistad, 252 pages, $25.99), Hurston had long been beguiled by the speech and customs of her hometown of Eatonville. The trouble, she later wrote, was that "I couldn't see [the culture] for wearing it." What she needed to bring her world into focus was "the spyglass of Anthropology to look through."

title: Mysteries: Her Sister's Keeper
summary: Philadelphia cop Mickey Fitzpatrick goes undercover and off the record in search of her troubled sister after someone starts murdering local addicts.. Michaela "Mickey" Fitzpatrick, the narrator of Liz Moore's powerful fourth novel, "Long Bright River" (Riverhead, 482 pages, $26), is a police officer sworn to protect and serve the citizens of her native Philadelphia. She keeps particularly close tabs on Kacey, her impulsive, irresponsible and drug-using younger sister. Though Mickey has always felt obliged to look after her sibling, inevitably the separate paths they've taken in life have caused a rift. "Officially," Mickey admits, "Kacey and I no longer speak to one another. We haven't for five years."

title: Five Best: Richard Snow on Lesser-Known Novels of World War I
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Disney's Land: Walt Disney and the Invention of the Amusement Park That Changed the World.'. By John W. Thomason Jr. (1926)

title: An Antarctic Explorer's Mental Journey
summary: Endurance athlete Colin O'Brady was the first person to cross the Antarctic continent alone and unaided-thanks to an epiphany with 77 miles to go. Fifty-three days into his solo trek across Antarctica and 77 miles from his goal, Colin O'Brady was exhausted and starving. Running out of food, he had stretched out his daily rations to keep himself alive. "My ribs were sticking out, my hips were sticking out," he recalls. "I had frostbite on my hands and cheeks." It was Christmas Day 2018, and he could barely summon the energy to pack his bags onto the sled he pulled behind him. But then he started and, step by step, something in him shifted: "My mind came alive. I said to myself, 'What if I don't stop? What if I just keep going?'"

title: Walmart Shuffles Executive Ranks After Holiday Season
summary: Retailer says chief merchant Steve Bratspies is leaving, names new U.S. operations chief. Walmart Inc. chief merchant Steve Bratspies is leaving the company as the country's largest retailer shakes up its executive ranks following the crucial holiday season.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Philippine volcano erupts near Manila, Warren and Sanders trade barbs after debate, Pelosi sends articles of impeachment to Senate and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Lee Iacocca's Los Angeles Mansion
summary: The high-profile automotive executive who died last year spent many years in this Tuscan-style home near the Hotel Bel-Air.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Schlumberger Plans U.S. Pullback as Shale Oil Drillers Struggle
summary: World's largest oilfield services company said it was focusing on international prospects after a tough year. The world's largest oil-field services company, Schlumberger Ltd. , is pulling back from the U.S. and focusing on international projects as a slowdown in shale drilling reverberates through the industry.

title: L.A. Home of Lee Iacocca Lists for $26 Million

Each makeover came with a new high-tech TV: first a 42-inch set, then a 50-inch, now a 65-inch with glorious 4K UHD resolution. title: A Most Excellent Egg Sandwich: Where to Find It, How to Make It
summary: Instagram is mad for the egg-salad sando. But have you tried the kind filled with tamagoyaki, the Japanese rolled omelet? Here's what you need to know. I LOVE THE WAY that in Japan, there always seems to be a sandwich close at hand, neatly wrapped and ready to go. At train stations, bakeries and the ubiquitous konbini, or convenience stores, "sandos" come filled with everything from fried pork cutlets to whipped cream and fruit, almost always on white bread with the crust cut off. Last year, egg-salad sandos had a stateside brush with celebrity thanks to the success of Konbi, a Los Angeles sandwich shop whose konbini-inspired version became an Instagram darling. With a whole hard-boiled egg at the center, revealing a sunny circle of yolk when the sando is sliced, Konbi's iteration is indeed photogenic. But for me the ideal sando filling is the layered and rolled style of omlelet known as tamagoyaki.

title: A Partisan Impeachment, a Profile in Courage
summary: JFK lauded the senator who bucked his party and voted to acquit Andrew Johnson.. The John F. Kennedy Library Foundation is accepting nominations for its annual "Profile in Courage" award. title: 'Drunk in China' Review: The Proletariat's White Wine
summary: Some say it takes 300 shots to learn to love baijiu. Beijing loves it so much it recently spent three times its defense budget on the drink..
